description: From Middle English worschippe, worthschipe, from Old English weorþsċipe. Synchronically analyzable as worth (“worthy, honorable”) +‎ -ship. Cognate with Scots worschip (“worship”).

entries.meaning: The devotion accorded to a deity or to a sacred object.
examples: Polytheistic theology and worship had to go underground.

entries.meaning: (Christianity, specifically) The adoration owed to God alone, as greater than the veneration that may be accorded to figures such as saints.
The religious ceremonies that express this devotion.
examples: The worship of God is an eminent part of religion, and prayer is a chief part of religious worship.

entries.meaning: (by extension) Voluntary, utter submission; voluntary, utter deference.

examples: In attitude and aspect formed to be / At once the artist's worship and despair.

entries.meaning: (chiefly Britain) Used as a title or term of address for various officials, including magistrates
(obsolete) The condition of being worthy; honour, distinction.

verbs.description: worship (third-person singular simple present worships, present participle (Commonwealth) worshipping or (US) worshiping, simple past and past participle (Commonwealth) worshipped or (US) worshiped or (obsolete) worshipt)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To reverence (a deity, etc.) with supreme respect and veneration; to perform religious exercises in honour of.
examples: When all our fathers worshipped stocks and stones.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To honour with extravagant love and extreme submission, as a lover; to adore; to idolize.
examples: With bended knees I daily worship her.
We worship at the church down the road.
